Can measure from 3mm to about 80mm.

I print with PLA, 33% infill, Brim and full support.

I've not been able to print the Gauge or Fasteners with threads that actually work, so the Gauge1/Gauge2 and Fastener models comes without threads, you need a 10mm metric tap and die (For M10 nut/bolts) and thread them yourself.

  1. Print Base.stl,Fastener.stl,and either Gauge1.stl or Gauge2.stl
  2. Use a 10mm tap/die to create threads on the gauge and fastener.
  3. Print e.g. http://www.vendian.org/mncharity/dir3/paper_rulers/UnstableURL/rules_cm_narrow_20cm.pdf on a printable sticker.
  4. Cut and align the printed ruler on the Base using calipers

The HeigthGauge_Fusion.f3d file is the original design from the Fusion 360 CAD software.

description.text:
Our Petporte Smartflap is mounted in a door facing east, with the current eastern wind the amount of draft that gets by the flap is significant. Since this comes directly into our living room I made this plug, surround the shape with silicone rubber anti drift strip from the hardware store (4-7mm) and it should fit fine.

The grip part turned out to be a bit smaller then I thought, probably better make it 12mm instead of 10mm to get a 24mm wide opening for the fingers. See the scad file.

title: Tronxy X5S conversion to cheap Ramps 1.4

description.text:
This is I believe Marlin 1.0.0
5th March 2018 Update, changed stepper motor current to 1200ma after more testing as homing z axis was proving to be a bit random where it homed.

Bonus! Pringles packaging to hold objects inside Pringles tube, just glue the lip on the disc's to the long part and the little handle to pull it out if you like.

Due to my brand new Tronxy X5S having a faulty mosfet on the extruder, which means it never turns off (Not good) I'm trying t get the supplier to send me a replacement board.

But I want to use it now! And I had a Ramps 1.4 I bought about a year or so ago just sitting in a box, so..............

Disclaimer! This is a work in progress, and not fully functional, but close enough to get good prints (PLA tested)
I tried to find a way to use a Ramps board to do this, but many clickbait links later, I decided to have a go myself.
I'm not an expert by any means in configuring firmware etc so please bear that in mind, it's just me releasing what works for me in case someone else need help.
The original X5S firmware setting have been used where possible.
Please bear in mind this is just the work of a couple of evenings and will no doubt need some clarification in places.

The Makerbot pic was printed on my converted printer and is shown being printed too, it looks pretty good to me, but maybe white doesn't really show very well in the photo.

Ok, what works and what doesn't

All of the stepper motors and hot end work fine.

The Heat bed, which is a biggie for the little Ramps board really needs an external mosfet to help it heat up, the transistors/mosfet's on this board were not made to run a heatbed this size, but I found if you keep the heat bed to 30 degrees it seems to cope Ok.

Hopefully the original LCD will work when I get a board to connect it up I've not tested it yet, but the problem might be that because this LCD unit has no sdcard reader built in, it may not be an ideal solution and you may have to use a different lcd unit and the firmware adjusted to suit..

The SD card reader also is enabled in the firmware but not present on mine yet so is untested.

So USB printing from Cura etc is working as far as I can tell.

The Z axis steppers connect to two separate connectors but share a stepper driver, so you will need to increase the driver current using a small pozi or philips driver.
The standard voltage measured on the driver is 560mv it needs adjusting to 1200mv or the z axis steppers will judder when moving up, you can try increasing in 200mv steps from the original 560mv, and test when homed to see if the steppers have any strength.
Compare how powerful the x and y motors are after homing by lightly turning them, they should be reasonably hard to move, the z steppers should be similarly resistant to you turning them.
The two z axis steppers are connected on the right hand side of the board, in my case I used male to female arduino patch cables about 20cm and plugged them straight (in the same order as the board pins) into the original z axis motor plugs
in my case grey lilac blue green into black green blue red. They are just too close together to plug directly into the ramps board.

I'll try to add a link in here so show the adjustment process.

Ok, in the photo of my ramps board, you can see the original steppers are plugged directly into the dupont pins on the board. This works perfectly, you don't need to cut off the old plugs and solder or crimp on new ends, the same goes for the for the temperature sensors and endstops.
Endstop warning!!
Do not use the bottom row of pins in the endstop bank of pins, it's the power + pin row, you WILL blow up your arduino's 5v regulator and you won't be happy!
My plugs are middle to top pin never the bottom pin!

The part cooling fan connects to the D9
The extruder body fan just connects to any 12v outlet you can find, (mine is wired to the 12 volt input)
Use Arduino 1.0.6 to install the firmware and you should be good to go.
Make sure you select your arduino model and com port.
Extract the files
There is a marlin.ino in there that you should select
Then upload to your Ramps board and you should be good to know, I'll test the sd card and lcd when I get the bits.

I would definitely recommend you add a cooling fan on this or the Ramps board may not last very long.

Please let me know if you spot any mistakes in the above.
See below Youtube video for how to set stepper current.

Mine are clockwise to increase current

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XU6lgFeZ7ZQ&t=231s

See http://domoticx.com/arduino-mega-shield-ramps/

For connections

title: The next beverage holder for people with disabilities

description.text:
This is my next version of the beverage holder for people with disabilities. It is designed to be adjustable in height and inclination. You can put a glass, cup or can in it. If you put a little ribbon around it, it keeps your beverage neatly in place, even if someone hits the table it is standing on. With its wide legs it is almost tip-over-proof.

The beverage holder consists of five parts: two screws, two legs and one plattform. Everything can be printed in about 9 hours.

I hope you enjoy my design. Make sure to check the video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zIda8vDgoi0) to see it in action. I design these kind of aids as a hobby. Please visit my website at https://makershelpcare.de/.

Cheers!

Nils

title: Nixon The Time Teller watch band

description.text:
As my original Nixon watch band broke, and as it is complicated to buy a new one (no after sales service), I've decided to design my own.
In order to have a nice quality I've redesign a little the band in order to have a flat surface which will be printed face down

Part 3 is simply glued in part 2.

If you struggle to create the bridge of part 5 then print part 6 and cut out the hole with a scalpel.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with Filaflex from Recreus
Heat bed: cold (no heat needed for the filaflex)
Hot end: 225°C
Part 3 and part 4 are standard PLA (HB: 75°C / HE: 205°C)
In order to obtain a nice print quality, the external side of the band must be printed face down.
As it is almost impossible to create a bridge with the Filaflex filament, I've created the part 4. Here is how it works:

  • Slice part 5
  • Insert the G-code M600 X30 Y30 Z10 E3 L0; just after layer 33 (just before the start of the bridge on layer 34). This code will pause the printing process
  • Launch the print (part 5 must be printed face down)
  • Once paused, place part 4 wrapped in a thin layer of aluminium in the middle of part 5
  • Resume printing, and the Filaflex filament will be supported by the part 4 in order to create the bridge.
  • When part 5 is printed, remove part 5 and the aluminium carefully
    Done !

This is just an addition to the AM8 upgrade I did based on the pheneeny design. I wanted to ensure that my bed was tracking perfectly perpendicular to the x-axis so I designed these little brackets that set on your 2040 extrusion and hold the bottom of the y-axis guide rod. You need to print two of these files so you can place one at the front and one at the back to ensure that your guide rod is perfectly straight. This places the bed almost perfectly in the center of the frame. I have also included the SolidWorks file so that you can customize the length if you need to locate your bed at a different dimension off of the outside frame rail.

title: PLOTS Spectrometer, ChemistryDude Edition V2.3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Version 3.0 is now available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49934. This is a spectrometer that straps onto an Android or iOS phone, tablet, or any camera capable of focusing very close (macro-mode) and allows you to collect spectra. Why would you want one? You can use it to identify the elemental composition of things (light bulbs, etc) based on the colors of light they emit. This version (2.3) reduces the number of parts to be printed, improves the light seal around the tube, and is MUCH sturdier than all previous versions.

Version 3.0 is now available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49934. This device consists of three different parts. The base has four pegs to catch rubber bands so you can quickly attach it to your phone, tablet, or camera. Even better, the bottom of the base is flat so you can glue it to a case that you can remove from your phone so you don't have to recalibrate it every time you put it back on. The holder holds the grating. The tube hold everything together. Assembly:

  • Cut a piece of grating (either holographic film grating or CD/DVD/BLRAY film) to fit over the holder. I found that 1000 lines per mm diffraction grating works VERY well and is available for less than US$3 from many scientific supply stores. This is the one I am using. http://tinyurl.com/9tjrz8r Hot-glue the grating to the plastic film with the grating lines parallel to the rectangular opening. Alternatively, you can hold it in place and tack the edges down with a hot soldering iron.

  • Use acetone to attach the holder to the angled end. There are three little flat platforms that hold it in place. It works best to slide the holder into position and then use a toothpick or very small paint brush to add acetone around the edges.

  • Cut a narrow slit in the solid end of the tube. The narrower the slit the better. A thin razor saw and works well. http://tinyurl.com/9e94f8e The slit needs to be as straight across two of the flat sides as you can make it and be parallel with the grating piece you already installed. Again, if this doesn't make much sense take a look at the pictures.

  • Strap it to your camera/phone/tablet and point it at a bright light. Fluorescent bulbs are great for this. You will see a rainbow of colors on your screen. If you look closely, you will notice the colors are not even. Instead, there are areas of light and dark. These light bars tell us what elements are present in the bulb. If you are using an Android device and the Opera browser you can go to http://spectralworkbench.org/ to capture, save, and share your spectra.
    • http://publiclaboratory.org/notes/warren/6-12-2012/mobile-android-version-spectral-workbench

title: Anet A8 Bearing shell / Lagerhülse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi.
After some research I found out that there are many diffrent opinions for the right replacement of the linear bearings.
I think I found out a good and also not so expencive way to get a good working bearing system.
I found some good Sinterbronze bearings on ebay
You will need Bearings like this: (8mm inner diameter x 12mm outer diameter x 20mm lenght)

https://www.ebay.de/itm/SELFOIL-Buchse-%C3%B88-x-%C3%B812-x-20-Sinterbronze/232262301650?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m1438.l2649

To fit in the original bearing block I designed a special shell which can be printed in vasemode so that there are no Z stop marks.
To print this in the right size please check my print settings

Deutsch:
Ich mach es Kurz da warscheinlich eh jeder Englisch kann.
Hab rescherschiert und bin der Meinung, dass man am mit sinterbronze Lagern gute Gleitlager hat, welche auch gut bezahlbar sind.
Obrige Link zeigt genau verwendete Lager.
Hab meine Hülle dafür so designed, dass man die Lager in die original anet a8 lagerblöcke einsetzen kann. Ist im spiralmodus gedruckt um keine z stopp nasen drin zu haben.
Damit das funktioniert muss wie unten beschrieben 0,3MM oder 0,1 mm für erste schicht sein und danach 0,2mm .
Und ganz wichtig ist boden / deckel Schicht auf 1,9 mm zu stellen.
So hat man den Anschlag absatz für die Hülse genau auf richtger Länge

Importent Note:
I printed This Shell in Vasemode with cura 3.0.4
To get the exact size you need to set the first layer to 0.3 mm oder 0.1 mm.
And also importent is, to set the bottom and top layer to 1,9mm .
You need this to get the right hight for the section with the smaller diameter.

This is a 3D printed version of the Printrbot Direct-Drive Aluminum Extruder. The design files are posted by the PrintrBot team here: https://printrbot.com/2014/01/23/aluminum-extruder-documentation-fun/ I had to import the "Alu Expolded.dae" from the above link into Google Sketchup, and save the individual parts as .stl files. I also used netfabb to rotate the top arm, so its easily printable on my Simple. Last weekend I assembled the 2014 version of the Printrbot Simple with the ALU extruder and was impressed with the results. These parts were printed using the same printer. I also own a factory assembled 2013 version of the PB Simple, with the Wooden Extruder. I have had some issues with it off and on, over the past few months. The Wooden Extruder has too many parts. This one has been designed well and I'm pretty happy with it. I plan to replace the Wooden Extruder on my 2013 Simple with these 3D printed parts of the ALU Extruder and see how well it performs. The STL files extracted from the original design are attached. The other parts used:
1.5" 6-32 screw
6-32 hex nut
16mm M5 screw
625 bearing
3/4" spring
The Exploded diagram to aid with assembly, posted by PrintrBot can be found here: http://d17kynu4zpq5hy.cloudfront.net/igi/printrbot/ZS6nDZNAcoXccUbq

description.text:
Utensil holders give people with limited grip, hand strength, or dexterity a way to use items like eating utensils, toothbrushes, writing tools, and other small items.  This device is focused on support for eating but the design could be extended easily to other objects. It was inspired by a post to the ATMakers.org page on Facebook asking for a utensil holder that accommodated knifes as well as forks and spoons. This design has several advantages over other designs:

  • It is 3D printable for just pennies using the most commonly used filament - PLA.
  • Separates the device into a hand mount and a utensil mount.  Each can be separately sized to accommodate differently sized hands and differently sized utensils.
  • The two components are joined using a common interface that can be extended for use with other objects like a pen holder or a hairbrush holder.
  • The utensil mount comes in two orientations to support both forks/spoons and knives.
  • The utensil mount attaches below the hand for a natural orientation.
  • The hand mount incorporates a thumb rest/guard to protect the thumb from being injured by the utensil or dragged through the food.

While a few STL files have been included for visualization you will actually want to download the file called UtensilHolderSTLFiles.zip. That file contains a wide variety of mount and fixture sizes. You will also want to go to this web page (https://wp.me/P9evBA-3n) to learn how to choose a set of files and how to assemble the components.

title: Anycubic Kossel E3D mount with 30mm and radial fan mount

description.text:
This part is replacing the original hotend mount on the effector for the Anycubic Kossel.
The original mount is weighing about 56g for the mount and cleat alone, so a good way to reduce the moving mass a lot.

This is work in progress, as the hotend is mounted with the lower fins in the effector, I fear some issues with proper cooling of these. Further, the heating block is larger than the Anycubic version, so you have to place the longer part facing to you. The auto leveing sensor then no longer works in front, as the space is simply not available. As I said, work in progress

The presented mount is ready for a 30mm fan for the hotend, which should fit just with a click. On the back, you will find a inlet for a radial fan.
I did not design a mount for the fan, to reduce printing time of the prototypes, but it will happen any time soon.

The top is fitting the E3D mount , I am just designing a counter part to screw. The holes are all 3mm, so please use a screw to cut the thread, no nuts needed.

Installation

  • insert the E3D v6 into the effector from underneath, longer part of the heat block facing you
  • press the top part into the mounting on the hotend
  • move up and place the cage, tighten the left screws from below the effector
  • now install the for fan for the hotend, by gently clipping in with the flexible right side of the cage
  • insert the remaining screws and tighten them all
  • done :-)

title: Falcon 9 Strongback at 85% with Open Girders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Falcon 9 Strongback at 85% with open girders. I opened up the solid spaces so they would more closely resemble the real thing and added some girder like embossing to the base.

This is scaled to 85% of the original to fit this Falcon 9 Heavy when it is scaled 85%. Even at this scale this is a very long print.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779030

Note: This version will not lay flat. Straight up and 20° tilt only.
Note: Based has holes to hold 48 USD pennies per side for added weight. They must be added during the print.

Build instructions:
Print one of each: bottom left, bottom right, T1, T2, and T3
Print two arms
Print 6 base alignment tabs
Print 4 upper alignment tabs

The alignment tabs fit into slots on the model in order to help line up the pieces while gluing them together.

Assembly order from bottom to top: Bottom Left and Right, T1, T2, T3.

****NOTE: All parts require supports while printing. Make sure that there are NO SUPPORTS AROUND THE AXLE of the bottom left and right prints. If supports are printed inside the axle tube, they are difficult to remove and may bond to the axle, breaking it when rotated.

The T1,T2,T3 parts can be printed vertically. But I print them front side down.

Secure with double sided foam tape. Drill and mount if you prefer, just ensure that the screw heads are flush with the inside of the base.

It's a fact that Chess is just more than a game.
I like to play this game because it touches my mind and certainly It's the best of all the games I have played. It not only gives good exercise to your mind but also teaches you about your life’s situational behavior, and that's I wanted to learn how to design my own Chess pieces and chessboard and I chose to do in SelfCAD https://www.selfcad.com because it's easier to learn yet powerful.

Printer Brand:

B9Creations

Printer:

B9Creator
Allow it to cool before using it

Designing Chess pieces and chessboard in SelfCAD Step 1. Creating the Base of the Chess Pieces

Select the Shape generator tool from the create section. Set the top and bottom radius to 30, height 7 and number of edges 60.
Add another segment by selecting "Add" and set the top and bottom radius to 25 and height 5.
Add another segment and increase the top and bottom radius to 30 and Finalize the shape.
Select the scale tool and scale it down to be as shown in the image above.
Select a Cube from the Basic shapes section and set the width, height and depth to 10, 80 and 10 respectively and finalize the shape.
Create five copies of the shape and place them in a circle. You can do this using copy offsets with pivot setting.Set the X and Y settings of the pivot to 15 and set the number of copies to 5 and click copy.
Select all the shapes and twist them using the Twist Tool.
Select Taper tool and adjust the shapes to be as sown in the 3rd image above. Select all and group them together.
To create the Top section of the base, select the Shape Generator tool from the Create section. Set the bottom and top radius to 20 and height 7. Add another segment and reduce the top and bottom radius up to 15 and finalize the shape.
Use the move tool to move it on Top of the shape you have created already as shown above.

Step 2: Modifying the Shape of the Chess Piece

Create a copy of the shape (CTRL + C) and move it beside the original shape.
Select a sphere, and set the radius to 10 and horizontal segment to 32 and finalize the shape.
Select align tool and set Align to Top and Reference to Mesh_2 in order to position it on top of the first shape as shown in the second image above.
Group the shapes and rename them as 1. Make the second shape taller by increasing the height of the middle section using Move and scale tools.
Drag a cube to the scene, skew, rotate and scale it down
Select the cylinder and set the top and bottom radius to 20 and height 30 then finalize the shape. Move it near the shape of the cylinder you just created.
Add another cylinder and set the top and bottom radius to 50 then finalize the shape.
Create five copies of the tapered shape using Copy offset after repositioning it (as shown in the 6th image above)
Subtract all the tampered shapes using the Boolean tool. You can do this by selecting all of them, click Boolean tool then Difference.
Scale the shape down and position it on top of the base as shown in the last image above.

Step 3: Creating the Third Piece of Chess

Copy the second shape without the top section.
Import an SVG horse model. Select the polygon selection tool, and select the areas in front and scale it down
Select the Sculpting tool and use it to make the model smoother.
Using the move and scale tools, move the model of the horse on top of the third shape as shown in the 4th image above.

Step 4: Creating the Fouth Piece of Chess

Create a copy of the 3rd image and scale it up a little bit up.
Select the cube from the basic shapes. Set the width, depth, and height to 20 and set all the segments 1 then finalize the shape.
Isolate the shape, select the Taper tool and scale it to be as shown in the 3rd image above.
Select Round corners tool and use it to apply round corners around the shape.
Select the Sphere, set the radius and horizontal and vertical segments to 10 and 32 respectively then finalize the shape, then position it on top of the other shape, as shown in the 5th image above.
Select a cube and set the width and height to 10 and depth 50 then Finalize the shape.
Scale it and position it on the shape as shown in the 6th Image above.
Subtract the rectangle using the Boolean then Difference tool.
Scale and position the model on top of the fourth shape.

Step 5: Creating the Crown

Create a copy of the fourth Image.
To create the top of the crown, select the cylinder and set the top and bottom radius to 20, height 25 vertical segments 12 then finalize the shape.
Select the Vertex selection tool and select every vertex and pull them up using the Move tool.
Add a sphere and position it in the middle as shown in the 3rd image above and group them together.
Position the crown on top of the base using the move and scale tools.

Step 6: Creating the Queen

Create a copy of the fifth piece (Crown).
After creating the base of the Queen, we need now to create the top of the Queen.
To do this, select the Shape Generator tool and set the top and bottom radius to 50, Bevel Offset -1 and Bevel level to 20 then finalize the shape.
Create another Shape using the Shape generator tool and place it on top of the previously created shape. Set the top and bottom radius to 30 and height 10 then finalize the shape.
Move, Rotate and position the shape of the other as shown in the 3rd image above.
Select the Sphere and set the radius to 20 then finalize the shape. Using Move, Scale and Align tools position the Sphere in the middle of the other shape.
Place the Shape now on top of the base.

Step 7: Creating the ChessBoard

Add a cube and set the Width to 100, height 20 and depth 100 then Finalize the shape.
Isolate it and using the Scale tool, make it the size of the workspace.
Select every polygon using the Polygon selection tool and set black color to the selected polygons as shown above.
Position the shapes according to the Chessboard.
Use copy tool to create a copy of each piece and position them as shown above.
Use copy offset tool to create multiple copies at ones of the pawns.
Change the color and add textures to the pieces.
Group the pieces and Mirror them using the copy offsets tool and change their color to black.
We have now finished everything. Select the workspace and delete it.

title: Smith and Wesson Shield Magazine extension

description.text:
This is a Smith and Wesson Shield magazine extension I designed for my Shield in 9mm. It is a work in progress still, will be making some small changes over the next couple of days. It extends the factory 7 round 9mm magazine to 9 rounds, or the factory 6 round .40 S&W magazine to 7 rounds, it might be possible to fit an 8th in, but I do not own a Shield in .40 to test that. The plug is to keep the baseplate from coming off the magazine when inserted in the gun, but it might require a little bit of fitting once it is done printing. The walls on the back of the baseplate are a bit thin and I will be making them thicker to lower the chance that it will break off when removing support. You could also print it flat and it will not have any support on it, so it will probably not break off, but then there will be support in the rails that is kind of difficult to clear out, but it works just the same and uses less plastic.

TODO:

• Increase depth of extension to make it easier to insert a full magazine on a closed slide.
• Increase thickness of back of extension to make it less likely to break when removing support.

description.text:
I've got several Raspberry Pi 3 that have been dedicated to permanent duties on my home network. The problem has been where to put them. They're too small to place on shelves. I looked into making a rack mount for them, but those projects seemed to big and involved.

Since I've organized my tools on a peg board, I thought I could dedicate some space on the peg board to mounting these handy little computers.

This design is a remix of several designs by me and others.

The case itself is a great design from @dktosoch who, in turn, reworked an original design by @walter (see the "Remixed From" section in the left column for details). The case has more heft than I think it needs to have, but it isn't a problem worth correcting.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used low

Infill:

solid for the pegboard part, not so solid for the case itself.

Notes:

Supports are needed only on the pegboard socket legs. The other parts do not require supports.

If you're using Simplify3D, its default settings won't properly produce supports. You need to set Extra Inflation Distance to 0.5mm and Support Pillar Resolution to 1.0mm.

1. The "Cap" piece is best installed at an angle first and then rotated into position. Ensure that the plastic is behind the tiny metal flanges on the USB sockets.
  2. Slide the RPi 3 into the case. For me the case is snug, but it doesn't take much force to slide in.
  3. Press with thumbs to get it to snap closed. It should look seamless.
  4. Should you ever need to open the case, use an old ethernet cable as a handle to pull the RPi from the case. It won't take much pressure, but you probably don't want treat a good cable that way.
  5. Mount the pegboard socket at a good location
  6. Slide the RPi into place
  7. Use the cable routers to neatly tack the cables to the pegboard.

description.text:
This is a stand for a handheld safety razor of the type which you have to screw together after inserting a blade.

I designed this for my Merkur travel shaver, which looks like this: http://amzn.to/2Fbs2VT

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

50%

Notes:

Print one copy of each STL file. I used PLA. While the other pieces should print without problems, the base plate may need special attention due to its size to prevent warping.

Assembly
  1. Use superglue or plastic glue to attach the shaft to the base plate.
  2. Glue the ring holder to the top of the shaft.
  3. Hold the assembly in place with a vise or a clamp so that one of the four notches on the ring holder faces upwards and is horizontal.
  4. Glue one of the rectangular holder plates to the ring so that the notch on the ring holder is glued into the recess on the back of the rectangular plate. Let it dry.
  5. Rotate the assembly by 90 degrees and repeat steps 4 and 5 for each rectangular plate.

Good bed adhesion is tricky, and sometimes it's tempting just to slap a brim on a big print and hope for the best. REMOVING that brim after the fact is often a huge pain, though.

I made these pac-man shapes to serve as micro-brims on the corners of square prints: place them in your slicer, scale them so they'll only be a single layer tall, and they do the work of a brim with less plastic and less clean-up.

This is a slight modification to the sear in Captain Slug's Caliburn. I've never read of Caliburns having catch issues with a fresh default sear, so it's entirely possible this modified sear only helps in my specific Caliburn (has some custom work done to it). Just in case anyone else is having catch issues with the default Caliburn sear, I thought I'd upload this.

In the image, the stock sear (orange) is laid the modified piece included here (grey). You can see how the modified sear adds a bit of material to change the angle of contact between the sear and plunger. Note that this absolutely increases the trigger force required to fire over the default sear, but for me it was this or no catching whatsoever.

So basically, if the default sear works for you (which it probably does based on my research), ignore this file.

title: DC Motor Extender
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Some cool ready to print tools require a certain DC motor you just can't find online with the exact dimensions needed. So I made an extender that you can just glue on top of your motor to make it fit!

--> Configurable OpenSCAD file!

  1. order a motor
    • same diameter as needed (if you find one that is like 0.5mm smaller just glue 2-3 sheets of paper on it to make it a litle bit thicker)
    • smaller height as needed (some websites state motor heights from the beginning or end of the shaft, others from this cylindrical elevation at the shaft, so be careful! Better buy a little bit shorter motor than a too large one!)
  2. download the .scad file and open it with OpenSCAD
  3. adjust the variables on the very top to make the extender fit onto your motor
  4. render and print
  5. glue it on top of your motor

I hope this helps! Leave a comment and let me know!

Example images:
I designed the extender because I wanted to build a PCB drill (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1846582) and I couldn't find any motor of the required height. Now it fits perfectly!

Anycubic i3 Mega

title: Tenor G Major (E4-C6) 12 hole Transverse Ocarina (WIP)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an attempt at converting the previous Alto C to a Tenor G. (Aiming for the range of E4 to C6)
This may not fit everyone's hands, and I'm hoping to be able to shrink some of the fingerholes by undercutting them a bit more to help with that.

V3 Sound Sample: https://youtu.be/YaNaFP12OAg

I've always wanted a deeper pitched ocarina than the one I had, but I could never justify dropping another 60 dollars for an ocarina which is only like 4 notes lower than my clay one. I'll still probably buy one in the far future, but this will tie me over until then.

Version Notes

• V3: This version is based off the V17 model of the Alto C. The model was scaled up, then the inner walls were scaled up slightly more (to thin the walls a bit, they were massive after just scaling the whole thing). The Voicing was re-finagled to fit the new size.
This one seems really loud to me and takes a bit more breath to play than I expected. The high notes work, but I think sound a bit airy.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 MM, Matter Control Medium Settings

Infill:

9%

Notes:

Wall thickness is more important than infill with this one.
I would recommend at least 1.2mm walls/perimeters.

Matter control has an unfortunate habit of throwing on a support that sneaks through one of the fingerholes and continues on the inside of the model. Not sure how to fix it yet.

Print Dimensions:
X: 57.53mm // 2.265 Inches
Y: 97.73mm // 3.848 Inches
Z: 160.14mm // 6.305 Inches

This took me just short of 9 hours, whereas the smaller alto was about 5.5 hours.

I don't expect anyone to ever use this!
If you own a HP mixed reality headset and your ipd is >67mm and somehow your set is out of warranty and compared to you McGyver is an amateur this might sharpen your image!
Short how-to:
Open your headset from the front working towards the rear. Use a saw to separate the two displays. Glue this spacer (print in ABS!) with a ABS solution in aceton/thinner between the now 2 displays. Remove the 4 mounting holes that would attach the display unit to the headset with a saw. Also cut the corresponding 4 stegs on the headset for those 4 screws by 2mm with a dremel tool. Enlarge the 2 holes for the lenses in the cover. Reassemble, tada!

The STL contains spacers for 6mm,6.3mm and 6.6mm. You can select a different spacer width in the included .scad file.

comments.text: Do you have any more pictures of the install? this looks sounds really promising!!!
comments.author: fiveseven808

comments.text:
Nope :(
I never thought
A: it would work
B: anyone else would be so daft to do this.
Anyway, the lenses+displays+mounting is the same as used by Acer, and you can find a teardown here: https://packet39.com/blog/2017/08/04/teardown-of-the-acer-microsoft-mixed-reality-vr-headset/
You'll need to make a cut in the middle (remove the glued on ir-sensor first), also remove ~4mm on either side so the spaced out lenses will fit in the limited space.
The lens unit consists of one big plastic moulding and a thin aluminum cover on the rear. I just cut through both of them at one go.
(I also drilled new holes and secured the alu cover with 4 additional screws near the cut to prevent it from getting loose as it is only secured with a few screws left+right, but i think you can glue everything in one go while glueing in the spacer).
Tip: when sawing/cutting the lensholder you need to avoid grabbing the unit(s) at the side of the flatcables of the displays, the cables are glued on, if they become loose your headset is trashed.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Chinese Lantern / 燈籠 / 鼓仔燈 / 花燈

The ancient Chinese sometimes captured fireflies in transparent or semi-transparent containers and used them as (short-term) lanterns. Raise the Red Lantern, a Chinese film, prominently features lanterns as a motif. Lanterns are used in many Asian festivals. During the Ghost Festival, lotus shaped lanterns are set afloat in rivers and seas to symbolic guide the lost souls of forgotten ancestors to the afterlife. During the Lantern Festival, the displaying of many lanterns is still a common sight on the 15th day of the first lunar month throughout China. In other Chinese festivities, the kongming lanterns can be seen floating high into the sky during Chinese festivities.

燈籠，臺灣古稱鼓仔燈，俗稱花燈，是種古老的照明設備，古埃及便已出現，在亞洲東部常被視作的一種傳統民間工藝品。

title: Pi Sphere
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just in time for Pi Day!
Teaching aid for basic geometry.
Designed for a dual extruder printer. There is not any clearance for the letters to be printed separately and glued in place.

There are two hemispheres. One half shows circumference, radius, and diameter. The other half shows area.

The base is made of 4 sides that have the value of pi and a few formulas using pi.

Print as follows, the + indicated a merge is needed in your slicer program:

  1. Area Half Sphere + Area letters
  2. CDR Half Sphere + CDR letters
  3. Pi Sphere Latch
  4. Pi Sphere stand top
  5. Pi Sphere stand base
  6. A Side + A letters
  7. V Side + V letters
  8. PI Side + Pi letters
  9. C Side + C letters

The Base components will need to be glued and assembled.
The latch is just to help retain the two hemispheres together while on the stand.

Design files from Brink Effects are provided for your reference only. By downloading the files, you assume responsibility to verify the design for your use and safety. Brink Effects cannot control how the files are used; thus Brink Effects does not hold any liability for the use of the files. Use at your own risk. Remember to keep small objects away from children and pets. Be cautious of sharp edges.

description.text:
The power of Vader compels you! He's not on any mercy missions this time.

Just another quick remix. I keep seeing more pop culture buddhas and like spreading the love around. I used the common Vader icons, and then stitched them together in Blender before validating the whole mess prints on my Prusa i3.

I've released a couple of different files with this print. VaderJesus contains the full model, you'll definitely need supports for this, but it prints fine. For people who don't mind gluing and hate big supports, I've also included a cut version divided into bottom and top, with the top half cut into left and right portions. Print all the pieces and then just glue together. It'll cut down on material usage and print time, but of course, glue.

Enjoy.

title: Watney rover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Watney is a low-cost Raspberry Pi-enabled FPV rover. It's easy to print, easy to assemble and easy to modify. If you make one, please post a picture here!

Please visit https://github.com/nikivanov/watney for more information about assembly, software setup, and configuration.

Parts:
All of these components can be found on Amazon, Ebay, AliExpress, Banggood and others.

  • Raspberry Pi Zero W
    If you live near a MicroCenter in the US, you could get one of these for $5. You also obviously need an SD card.
  • Raspberry Pi Camera with Zero-compatible cable
    I used a Raspberry Pi Camera v2, but you can get a cheap camera on ebay for about $9 if you search for "raspberry pi zero camera". You can also use the fish-eye version to get a better field of view or the IR version to have night vision.
  • USB power bank that provides at least 1A
    Bigger is better as long as it fits on the roof
  • 2x Arduino geared DC motors (Amazon | AliExpress)
  • L298N H-bridge controller (Amazon | AliExpress)
  • Jumper wire 10cm or longer (Amazon or any other set of 10mm jumper wires)
  • M3 screws (Amazon or any other M3 set)

The major components (minus wire and screws) can be bought for around $40 depending on where you live.

title: Audio Technica ATH-910 PRO headset earcup holder repair

description.text:
This is a couple of repair parts for the Audio Technica ATH-910 PRO headset. The files include the main earcup holder and the tiny clasp used in the back to hold it onto the main pin. These pieces will work on either side.

I recommend a decently solid amount of infill, as you want this piece to be somewhat strong. Because it is so thin, I also think 0.1 mm layer height is the way to go, but my prototypes at 0.2 mm were decently strong as well.

You need the support under the pins, but if you put support everywhere, it will fill in the hole for the pin and clasp. It is possible to pull this support out in more or less one piece, but you'll need small pliers. If you think your printer can handle bridging the rectangular gap, just support the pins.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

60%

How to disassemble the old holder, and reassemble with the new one

Removing the old rectangular clasp will likely be the most difficult and time-consuming part since it is so recessed and has little gap for a prying tool. But if you can remove it without breaking it, I recommend using it over a weaker printed replacement. Once the clasp is out, the fork should fall right off the main metal pin.

Next, you can remove the earcup. There are two plastic pins holding it in place. If one of them is broken off like mine was, you'll have no trouble getting the earcup off. Otherwise, you need to locate and remove the rounded pin first, before pulling the straight pin side. Place the earcup in the new holder in the reverse order (straight pin side first, then rounded), and then attach the holder to the metal pin via the clasp. You can re-use the old stickers as I did.

The fit may not be perfect depending on your printer, and you may need to scrape the hole for the pin or clasp with a small knife.

description.text:
The iron holder that came with my Hakko FX-951 station appears to have room for a roll of solder but includes no parts to do so.

This thing is basically just a pipe to support a spool of solder and let it spin freely. Inner diameter 6.6mm, outer diameter 18mm, 73.4mm long. It's held in place with a piece of threaded rod and a nut on each side.

The tip of the iron sits about 15mm above the solder spool, which might be uncomfortable for some but I've had no issues.

title: Filament Spool Winder for Dremel 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spool winder bit designed to interface with the Dremel Idea Builder filament spools and a power drill. It may also work with the Flashforge Dreamer and the Flashforge Inventor. My intention was to be able to transfer filament from generic spools onto my empty Dremel brand filament spools in order to be able to house more exotic filament types (not available from Dremel) directly inside my 3D printer.

Although the resulting part was a perfect fit and I was able to rapidly transfer filament as I had originally intended, I quickly realized that the tension applied onto the filament during the transfer process was too excessive and the transferred filament began to breakdown after a few days. I believe that transferring filament is an art and I have since decided to not bother with internal filament spools anymore.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Recommend 6 shells/perimeters and 6 top layers for strength.

Unlike some of my other prints, this one went very smoothly. I only made two versions of this spool winder. I measured the gap dimensions of the target spool and the dimensions of a drill bit so that I could interface with both. The first version had sharp edges so I smoothened them in the second version.

I was getting really tired of juggling all my junk on my way into work. So, I figured a lanyard would allow me to strap my (Knock off) Yeti to my lunch box that way I needed one less hand.

This is the result. I wanted it to have some visual interest so I did the skeleton hands to give me surface area to glue to and - of course - to make it look cool.

This is permanently glued to the cup with CA glue so.. . . Don't put it on your wife's cup without permission.

This was designed for use with a lanyard but it would easily serve as an anchor for one of those para-cord survival nut handles or anything else. And, of course, you could mount it on anything. You have my express permission to put it on your phone, your remote, your dog, whatever.

It prints flat. I used a little heat to shape the main body but not the fingers. They are bendy by design. Although the gaps are small enough that I had to Crack the knuckles to get them to bend. Much like my own fingers.

I just realized that (it appears) I can post the *.dwg file. I hope this actually works and that someone finds it useful. I may have to go back and post it on previous stuff I put up.

I used the original which was good, but then customized it to fit the printer I use so that if someone wanted, it could span the full length. Watching the printer after a bit thinking about what I'm trying to actually achieve and what I really needed I trimmed and streamlined further. I get the ridged frame I need, less added weight, and a touch neater in appearance. Yes I've actually combed the wires in the harness on my printer so looks do count. I'm odd that way.

Inspired by the contraption from the 1930's: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WaAHiiCnteY

I noticed the dotted line tool had all the components creatable in a few 3D printed pieces. I decided to give it a try. This tool has come a long way since my first iteration, but could certainly be improved. I can already think of a more efficient mechanism for this tool and I'd love to see someone else come up with it too!

Tool has holes for permanent assembly with machine screws, but can be used without. The gear is designed to be interchangeable.

Print the pen grip vertically, and the rest of the arm flat on the bed. Both components need to be printed in different orientations to be smooth on the gears, and strong when gripping.

The drive wheel has trouble gripping the table. I applied a thin layer of hot glue around the edge for tons of grip.

Enjoy!

author: cxam5

title: Evader ST Pro Suspension Mounts and Spacers (DTXC9584 Replacement)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I measured and modeled my NIP DTXC9584 Suspension Mounts and Spacers. They aren't 1:1 but all the important spots should line up. I'd recommend just purchasing steel washers/spacers from your local hardware store if you can or otherwise reusing your original parts but otherwise I have included those models as references. Original parts seem to be made of stainless steel (washers) and injection molded nylon (mounts). Left and right mounts are identical. Print two copies and then rotate one on assembly. Per the stock part, these mounts are 3 degrees offset by default but should allow adjustment since they have two sets of holes (tested, see pictures).

These parts will ONLY fit an Evader ST Pro or any Evader using the ST Pro Rear Chassis Plate (DTXC7017). Please see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2805641 for a part that will fit other models.

Change Log:

V1: Initial Release -- PLA printed model fits for three of the four holes. Holes are ridiculously tight and a little too far inside.

V1.1 1: Wrong model uploaded -- I made some incremental changes and just forgot to export the model so I uploaded an older version

V1.1 2: Ditto -- I just uploaded the completely wrong file

V1.1 3 (Currently uploaded file: Fourth hole has been moved .4 mm to allow for all possible mounting angles. Additionally, I have enlarged the holes so that finishing work should not be required for printed models -- PLA printed model has been tested successfully with the OEM aluminum plate but has not yet been installed on my Evader. Will test shortly but everything looks good. See pictures.

author: deadcereal

description.text:
*** PREFACE: I AM NOT ENDORSING NOR AM I AFFILIATED WITH FAB365.NET IN ANY WAY. THIS IS SIMPLY SOMETHING I STUMBLED UPON AND SAW A FUN OPPORTUNITY WITH. I included the STL only because it is required to post a design.

Alright you made it past my warning :) I thought this was something creative and I could have made my own model of it, but... I wanted to give the site credit for what I came across - so I purchased their VW Van STL liscense (leave out your criticism, I know this is supposed to be an open source community I am sorry I cannot give you the STL files!) if you would like to procure the files for yourselves please visit fab365.net.

CHANGES: What I changed from the original files you will obtain from fab365.net is I scaled everything down to 0.7 of original size using RepetierHost. I then bought some neodymium magnets from Micro Center (you may or may not be able to buy them cheaper online). I used a soldering iron to heat inset the magnets into the completed model. ***NOTE: IF YOU ARE NOT FAMILIAR WITH MATERIAL SCIENCES OR MAGNETISM, HEATING THESE MAGNETS WITH A SOLDERING IRON WILL ELIMINATE THEIR MAGNETIC PROPERTIES.

  • SOLUTION: Heat ONE magnet to create your impression and then inlay UNHEATED magnets into the cavity and repeat...

As always, if you have any questions or comments please feel free to reach out!

title: Gloomhaven hex dial monster base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A hex base for gloomhaven monsters, the outer ring is numbered 1-18 and the center rotates for keeping track of monster HP. The front slot is for holding modifier bits.

The print in place version is actually a total redesign with a tighter fit, thicker, more solid piece holder, cleaner font, and the pointer arrow is engraved rather than embossed.

GHd12v2 is a print in place 12 sided dial - i have not printed this yet, it is experimental.

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

50%

Notes:

Smaller layers will increase quality a lot, as the numbers are engraved on a chamfered edge.

The dial and ring as separate parts come apart easily but are held in place by the cardboard insert while in use.

The print in place option has pretty low tolerance as I wanted a tight fit that clicks into place at the center of each number.

If the dial doesn't turn, rather than twisting it (I snapped the first one trying to twist it free) try supporting the outside ring with a bottle cap and gently tapping the center part from the top and bottom - I used a small screwdriver and hammer for this.

title: Test Tube for Capturing Queen Ants

description.text:
This is a test tube I made for the specific purpose for capturing Queen ants. The test tube is 16mm in diameter so you should be able to catch a wide range of queens, from the smallest monomorium to the largest myrmecia.

Also please before you go out and catch queens that you do sufficient research so that you can take care of your queen properly, be sure to know whether your queen is claustral or semi-claustral.

There are two types of test tubes, one with two division (two slits) and the other with four divisions (four slits), both are 16mm.

POST PRINTING:
After you have printed the tube out you should have a cylinder that has four slits or two slits in the sides depending on which version you are using. In order to prepare the tube to capture ants, you must do the following steps:

  1. fill the test tube with water just below where the slits start.

  2. After the water level is appropriate stuff a cotton ball down into the tube so it soaks up the water. (MAKE SURE NOT TO STUFF IT ALL THE WAY DOWN), this will provide your queen with hydration and provide the test tube some humidity which will cause your queen to lay eggs.

  3. After the cotton ball is secured grab a roll of tape (MUST BE SEE THROUGH) and wrap it around the test tube making sure you leave no gaps in the slits, this will be your observation window.

  4. This step is optional, but crab a cotton bud, (the ones you clean your ear with), and rub the exposed tape on the inside of the test tube with the cotton bud, this is so you reduce the stickiness of the tape.

  5. You can use a second cotton ball as a sealer if you catch any ants, cotton balls are porous meaning air can flow in and out which is ideal.

  6. Go out in the sun and catch yourself some ants

Thanks for reading and hope this test tube is very helpful

author: SamMacZee

title: Duratrax Battery Strap & ESC Mount Evader EXT2 (DTXC6305 Replacement)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement for the battery strap and ESC mount of the Evader EXT2. The ESC mount will work with all Evader chassis, including the ST, ST Pro, EXT, etc but the strap will only work on an EXT2 or any other Evader that is already equipped with this ESC mount. This strap / mount combo will allow you to use LiPo batteries with your Evader or just replace the old strap that has been lost or broken.

I'd recommend printing the strap sideways with supports (rotated 90 degrees). I have not been able to get a successful print when oriented as presented in the STL with or without supports. The ESC mount prints best upside-down. Supports may be necessary if your printer can't handle overhangs but it printed fine for me without supports.

The strap is a replacement for DTXC6305 or DTXC6290 if printed with the ESC mount as well, however since DTXC6305 is still sold by Hobbico (manufacturer of the Evader, via TowerHobbies), I'd recommend using that part instead.

I believe the stock screws are 2xM3x10 to attach the ESC mount to the chassis. Foam between the battery and the strap is not required but definitely recommended.

You'll also need a rod of some sort to finish the hinge- insert it through the holes in the back and cover to connect the two parts.

title: Wall Mount for Philips Hue Hub 2.1

description.text:
Simple mount plate that uses one (or several) 3M Command Strip adhesive tapes to mount the Hue Hub in a convenient location on the wall.

The Hub sits very flush against the plate because there are recesses for the rubber anti-skid pads to sit in. In fact, this prevents the Hub from popping off the mounting stud. As you slide the hub down over the mounting stud, you will hear the "feet" click into the recesses.

To remove the baseplate, the baseplate will have to be bowed a little so the feet come out of the recesses, allowing the hub to be lifted off the mounting stud. I put my command tape centered under the stud, so it will be difficult to remove. I should have put two command tapes at the analog clock positions corresponding to 10:30 and the 1:30 positions. This way the mounting plate will bow outwards by pulling the hub gently away from the wall, then sliding it up off the mounting stud once the rubber feet are clear of the recesses.

The mounting stud can be fragile, so I made it so you can put a 5mm long 3mm or 2.5mm machine screw and nut through it to keep it from snapping off.

Once the hub is removed, the baseplate can be un-mounted by gently pulling on the command tape tab(s) in the center hole of the baseplate, causing the tape to slowly release from the wall without causing any damage.

MP Select Mini

I printed the stud at 0.100mm/layer for improved strength, as well as to ensure that the underside of the stud was smoother. This helps it slide into the keyhole on the back of the hub much easier.

description.text:
Baseplates for the game GKR (Giant Killer Robots).
These allow the health of a unit to be displayed on their baseplates rather than unit cards, making it more visible to other players at a glance.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Infill can be low but will use basically the same amount of filament but 100% should give the best surface finish

Unit Bases
To print a HP base for all support units and mercs you will require these quantities:
5 x 1HP base
6 x 2HP base
5 x 3HP base

(You can decide whether or not it is worth having bases for units with 1HP or not as you could just remember that any units without a base have 1HP)

If you have Big Little Buddy you will also require:
1 x BLB

Pegs/HP Markers
If every single unit is in play at the same time (unlikely) you will require:
37 x Pegs

Inserting

The tolerances on these are designed so they fit TIGHT.
To attach base you will need to click in each point of the base one at a time:
1: place rear edge of unit against inner edge that has HP peg holes
2: while slightly flexing the printed base down work your way clockwise by pushing the corners of the unit into the base
3: pegs should push into the holes firmly but may require pushing in and out a few times for goldilocks fit

title: DELL 7001080-Y100 PSU Mod for Zaribo 3030 Aluminium Extrusion

description.text:
DO THIS MOD ON YOUR OWN RISK.

This is a custom design for DELL 7001080-Y100 PSU for 3030 Aluminium Extrusions.

You need a 40x40x40 silent fan, a W1209 thermostat and a Power Switch

As this PSU is meant to work with a Dell server, it does not have a cooling system onboard so if you want to use it with your 3d printer build, you have to add a fan because it locks it self because of overheat.

This is a bit advanced modding so if you are not familiar with electronics DON'T DO IT. For this mod you have to remove the handle and the power input of the PSU and extend the power input cables inside the PSU and take them out from the bottom. And don't forget to add a 12v cable for the fan in vice versa direction.

Use AWG14 cables for this mod. 12v ports are 3 negative and 3 positive which are paralel behind. See the picture for pin connection in order to run when you power it. With this pin mod you don't need a motherboard soft switch in order to boot the PSU.

Power Switch
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Red-Light-Power-Rocker-Switch-Fused-IEC-320-C14-Inlet-Power-Socket-Fuse-Switch-Connector-Plug/32679674596.html

Thermostat
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/THGS-DC-12V-Thermostats-Temperature-heat-sensor-switch-50-110-degree/32729521814.html

description.text:
Last season of snowboarding I started thinking of getting a stomp pad. It was soon forgotten until next family ski trip was coming up. I decided to print myself a stomp pad but did not find one I liked. So I decided to make one myself.

The stomp pad is designed to either be glued or taped to the board. I used extremely strong double sided tape which was water resistant and could handle temperatures ranging from -40C to 70C. In addition I wanted the pentagram to stand out more so I decided to try painting it with nail polish. I have never tried this before so It was somewhat of an experiment. I painted it with three coats and let it dry in between.

I recently tried it in the slopes and works great! I does not move at all and fills its purpose. The nail polish held unexpectedly well and from what I could see it did not wear at all.

The pentagram itself was inspired by this thing made by user IWorkInPixels.

Here is a link to the Fusion 360 file if you would like to tinker with it yourself!

First picture is after a week in the slopes
Second picture is directly after painting

description.text:
The Martenitsa is a bulgarian traditional gift - usually a small piece of adornment, made of white and red yarn and usually in the form of two dolls, a male and a female. Nowadays it can be just any object with red and white color, attached to a red and white string.
Martenitsi are worn from Baba Marta Day (March 1) until the wearer first sees a stork, swallow, or blossoming tree (or until late March). The name of the holiday means "Grandma March" in Bulgarian and the holiday and the wearing of Martenitsi are a Bulgarian tradition related to welcoming the spring, which according to Bulgarian folklore begins in March. Inscribed in 2017 on the UNESCO Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

Check out my website http://lokspace.eu for more cool projects! And don't forget to tip if you like what you see ;)

description.text:
Dovetail puzzle box. Clearance between the two pieces is 0,15mm. You need an accurate printer for this tolerance but the spacing will be perfect, so that you won't be able to see the steel ball, which is responsible for the locking mechanism.

I had made a 0,3 clearance model first. It will fit easier but due to the bigger spacing the steel ball can been seen if looking into the spacing directly, which destroys the tinkering quite a bit.

The magnet needs to be placed on 4.68mm z-height. Place the M0 command in the G-Code before this line or pause manually or place the magnet while printing. There is quite some time while the printer is printing the infill (or simply slow down the print).

To complete this puzzle you'll need:

11mm steel ball
8x3 neodym magnet

Caution:
The nozzle usually is a magentic material, so the nozzle tyoically would attract the magnets. The magnet holes have 8.3mm diameter. In my case they simply don't fall into the whole and I have to push them in with some force, which is good, so that the nozzle is not able to attract the magnet ;-)
If the hole tends to become to big, so that the magnet is not beeing hold in place well, use a drop of hot glue or something similar to fix the magnet during printing.

title: BloqChain - Easy Zero Infill Chain Links

description.text:
The BloqChain is my answer to the 3D printed chain link quest. I did a fair amount of research on this subject as I needed a sturdy chain to hang my (upcoming) PowerBloq thing from the workshop ceiling. None of the chains I found were able to deliver my three asks:

  • Two parts for easy assembly
  • Sturdy at 0% infill
  • No weakness introduced due to FDM printing

The resulting chain is already pretty sturdy at 0% infill with 2 perimeters, top and bottom layers printed at 0.25 mm layer height. Printed at 10% infill, 3 perimeters, top and bottom layers I could not break the chain.

Mission accomplished, BloqChain is a success. I might add complete chain so that not each link needs to be assembled. Also sturdy wall and ceiling mounts are almost finished in my brain, yet will have to be modelled, still.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

0-10%, 2-3 perimeters, top and bottom layers

Notes:

I did not have to print neither brim nor skirt for this on my MK2S. The BloqChain printed well without infill and very few perimeters, top and bottom layers.

At zero infill I was able to print quite a few chain links off of the last few inches of filament. This is currently my favourite way of getting rid of filament leftovers.

The more infill the more strength of course but don't overdo it on the infill because even at 10% infill I was not able to break the chain without risking injuries.

Some assembly required

The BloqChain halves should be press-fit together and should stay like this assuming your printer cannot print a glossy surface across layer lines. In case your printer is so well adjusted there is no friction across layer lines just a drip of super glue should fuse the parts together well.

The main strength is not the friction fit. There should not be too much pull perpendicular to the chain link length.

Let me know if you encountered strength issues at 10% infill. In case you test the strength with weights or such, please share where the chain breaks. Thanks and cheers!

Dogecoin (/ˈdoʊʒkɔɪn/ DOHZH-koyn, code: DOGE, symbol: Ð and D) is a cryptocurrency featuring a likeness of the Shiba Inu dog from the "Doge" Internet meme as its logo. Introduced as a "joke currency" on 6 December 2013, Dogecoin quickly developed its own online community and reached a capitalization of US$60 million in January 2014.

Compared with other cryptocurrencies, Dogecoin had a fast initial coin production schedule: 100 billion coins were in circulation by mid-2015, with an additional 5.256 billion coins every year thereafter. As of 30 June 2015, the 100 billionth Dogecoin had been mined. While there are few mainstream commercial applications, the currency has gained traction as an Internet tipping system, in which social media users grant Dogecoin tips to other users for providing interesting or noteworthy content.

This is a fully functional children's walking bike, ment for small children age 1 to 3.

In addition to all 3D printed parts, you will need the following parts:

  • 1 meter long 8 mm threaded bar
  • 5x Z608 (8 mm) bearings. (2x needed for front wheels, 2x needed rear wheels, 1x needed for lower front fork)
  • 4x 8 mm bolts with 60 mm length (for connecting the two chassis pieces).
  • 2x 6 mm bolts for mounting the seat.
  • 4x-8x 8 mm washers. The washers are used as spacers between the bearings and nuts.
  • 11x 8 mm nut for mounting the wheels and front fork. For each shaft, 2 nuts are needed to secure the shafts to the bearing and 2 nuts are needed to fasten the wheels.

The 8 mm threaded bar is cut to length for the wheel shafts and front fork. The remaining part can then be inserted horizontally into the chassis pieces for added strength (Although it was found that even without this reinforcement, the chassis is capable of supporting 65 kg easily).

This walking bike was designed by me in OpenSCAD for my son.

(At the moment of writing, it is in his skillful hands, undergoing extensive trials).

Printer:

Creatbot DE/DE Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

40%-50%

Notes:

All parts except the second chassis part (the blue part in the pictures) can be printed without supports.

For the bike shown in the pictures, all parts except the hubcaps were printed in PETG.
Tires were printed in TPE.
Hubcaps were printed in PLA.

All parts were printed with 4 shells (1.6 mm) and at least 40% infill.
For the handlebar, I used 4 shells and 70% infill for extra strength (it is the part most pulled/pushed on).
The saddle could be covered afterwards with a piece of cloth, but so far, this has not proven to be necessary.
Hubcaps are preferably glued on the wheels to cover the shafts and to prevent them from falling off.
Please make sure that the shafts used for the wheels are not too long.

Also deburr all metal parts after cutting to avoid possible injury. Also remove any sharp edges from strining or printer defects before mounting.

Please note that the tires are a very tight fit and can be difficult to get around the wheels.
Please also note that this bike takes a long time to print.

Total weight of the bike completed is around 3.7 kg.
Please remember that small children need to be supervised when playing with toys that might result in hitting/riding into objects or falling down.

description.text:
This is a parametric version of the excellent Gyroscopic Keyring by
gianfranco found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1307100

Thanks gianfranco!

I wanted to be able to experiment with the number of rings, spacing between
rings, sizes, etc. so created this parametric version that allows the
customizer in OpenSCAD or the Thingiverse customizer to be used to alter the
model.

Note that you are encouraged to make your own customized version since I'm only providing one simple STL as proof of concept. I'll add more STLs of different variations if there is a need.

The default settings will generate a model that is almost identical to the one above, but using the customizer, either the one built into OpenSCAD from the latest development snapshot versions (these are very stable), or the Thingiverse one, you can modify many settings to generate your own version by:

  • changing the inner ring size and central hole size - this affects the final gyro size
  • setting the gap size between the rings
  • setting the thickness of the rings
  • setting the height
  • adding an optional key ring loop - this can also be customized in different ways and orientation

With the OpenSCAD customizer (not sure if this can be done with Thingiverse customizer) you can also get a centre sliced view with some transparency in the rings to get a better view of what the model will look like in the centre - this may help decide if your printer tolerances would allow a good print, or just to see what the centre looks like since you never see it after a print :-)

Printer:

Own built Kossel variant

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

My printer is a single extruded and I do multi colour prints by changing filament during the print.

Designed in OpenSCAD using the sphere function to generate hollow balls that fit around each other concentrically, and then slicing top and bottom.

Most options are parametric and can be configured via the Customizer built into the latest OpenSCAD development builds. Using the customizer in OpenSCAD makes it easier to test and modify the code.

Using the openSCAD customizer to see a centre sliced view of a 3 ring gyro.

I use an external editor for coding, so that is why you do not see the code panel in the screenshot above.

The code is fairly modular and well commented and should be fairly easy to extend.

It's also available on github here:
https://github.com/fitzterra/3DP/commits/master/Things/GyroRingGenerator

comments.text: HI I just printed one with 20 rings at the default height and other default parameters.  I think the height has to be bigger to lock the rings in. as is the rings ulock with a 45 degree offset.   What do you think?
comments.author: wepollock

comments.text:
Hi @wepollock - I have not tried with so many rings, but I've seen this happen when the height is too low.
Of course, making it higher you start risking the smaller rings in the center not being sliced at all, so there would be an upper limit of where number of rings and height becomes impractical. This could possibly be adjusted to some point by making the central ring diameter a bit larger.
Depending on how well your printer is tuned, you could also try decreasing the gap between the rings slightly, but with low outer rings, this may not help much.

author: luisjm

title: Ball jointed cable management for Prusa MK2S/Zaribo - X Motor

description.text:
This is a ball jointed cable management system for the X Motor wires on the Prusa i3 MK2s and Zaribo 3d Printers. Note that the MK2S adaptor is coming soon so this is only currently usable for the Zaribo printer. For more information on Zaribo click here - http://zaribo.org/

You can find this same cable management for the heatbed here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2735303

And for the Extruder wires here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2787748

There are 3 main elements to this system:

The X Motor Adaptor:

  1. There are 2 of these, one is for attaching the adaptor directly to the Motor - This is for those who find that the motor wire is too short to reach the rambo box when using a Zaribo 320.

  2. The other is for attaching directly to the Zaribo X motor holder version 2 which can be found here - https://github.com/Zaribo/Zaribo-MK2/tree/master/STL

Ball joints - Approximately 17 of these will be required for the Zaribo. These are printed using 'Spiralise' or 'Vase' mode without any top or bottom layers. I recommend that these be printed with PETG so they have a little flex.

The Rambo box adaptor - Zaribo - This is similar to the ball joints but is straight on one end so it can fit over the existing Rambo connection, it should be a tight-ish fit.
This adaptor must also be printed using 'Spiralise' or 'Vase' mode. I recommend that these be printed with PETG so they have a little flex.
When the ball joints are pushed together they should be quite a loose fit but not fall apart.

TIPS: When threading the wires through the ball joints, do it in segments to make it easier then just joint the segments together afterwards.

description.text: Card tray for all GKR cards. Fits perfectly in the Core Box space, enough room for the Hapsi can.
Using 6mm Acrylic. Undersized to try to get a tight fit.

I really disliked the cup holders in my 2016 Outback as my coffee cup always clanked around during my commutes so the first thing I did when I got a 3D printer was come up with and insert for the cup holder. I designed this around my nozzle, 0.40mm with (2) perimeters and (4) solid bottom layers. Printing it like that makes it somewhat flexible when printing with PETG. In any event it should print fairly fast using minimal material and will work quite well. I made the ID to accommodate my Starbucks travel cup, 71.5mm ID and beveled the upper lip so the cup will slide into the holder without fuss...

remixed_from.title: Slide on balcony door handle - Aufschiebbarer Türgriff für Balkon

title: Slide on / Clip on balcony door handle - Aufschiebbarer Türgriff für Balkon, Ziehgriff, Schüco

description.text:
This handle is made for a Schüco Slide/Clip on door handle: https://ersatzteile.schueco.com/Kunststoff/Tuerziehgriff.html or https://www.amazon.de/Sch%C3%BCco-T%C3%BCrziehgriff-Balkont%C3%BCren-Terrassent%C3%BCre-Ziehgriff/dp/B01AMIUH2U/

We have so many broken door handles here that it was a economic decision to print a durable one. I have it printed in white PETG. Bear in mind that the sun will remove nearly all color from your filament over time, so white is probably the best. Nylon, ASA and Colorfabb XT would probably work good, too. ABS could get brittle over direct sunlight. Depending on where you live PLA might not be the best choice either especially when it is hot outside and it'll also absorb water. Check your favorite filament for outdoor capability.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print it upright (not flat), then you won't have any problems with overhangs.

0.3 layer height at 30% infill is plenty strong already with PETG, I can't even break it if I wanted to. The mount would break first.

I took Darki5000's door handle as inspiration and made my own, since unfortunately his has other dimensions.

All kinds of Fusion360 design files are included so you can easily adapt it to your own dimensions in case you need something different.

It was a good opportunity to learn designing with Fusion360, it was a while since I did something :)
